title: VTI Aero: GPS-Independent Indoor Localization
subtitle: Multi-Sensor Fusion for Autonomous UAV Navigation
description: Developed GPS-independent localization system for autonomous UAVs using multi-sensor fusion, computer vision, and Kalman filtering to enable precise indoor navigation where GPS signals are unavailable.

body.title: Technical Challenge
paragraphs: GPS-based navigation fails in indoor environments, tunnels, and urban canyons where satellite signals are blocked or unreliable, creating a critical gap in autonomous UAV capabilities.
Traditional dead reckoning approaches accumulate drift errors over time, while vision-only systems struggle with lighting variations, occlusions, and computational constraints on embedded hardware.

body.title: Implementation
paragraphs: Engineered a multi-sensor fusion architecture combining inertial measurement units (IMU), optical flow, visual odometry, and depth sensors to estimate position and orientation without GPS dependency.

Implemented Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) for sensor fusion, combining high-frequency IMU data with lower-frequency but more accurate vision-based position estimates to maintain drift-corrected localization.
Developed computer vision pipeline using feature detection (ORB, SIFT) and visual SLAM techniques to extract pose information from onboard camera feeds in real-time.
Optimized algorithms for embedded deployment on resource-constrained UAV flight controllers, achieving real-time performance with minimal latency.

body.title: Impact
paragraphs: Enabled autonomous UAV navigation in GPS-denied environments with centimeter-level accuracy across extended flight durations.
Successfully demonstrated indoor waypoint navigation, obstacle avoidance, and autonomous landing using only onboard sensors.
System architecture designed for portability across multiple UAV platforms and indoor/outdoor transition scenarios.
